document.docAuthor: Kaczmarek, Łukasz, Bartels, Paul J., Roszkowska, Milena & Nelson, Diane R.

subSubSection.paragraph:

Richters, 1909

n. sp. (
Pollock 1970 a
)

Record numbers (Sea/Ocean classification): Adriatic Sea: 13 , Atlantic Ocean: 2 , Balearic Sea: 3 , Baltic Sea: 1 , Ionian Sea: 15 , Mediterranean Sea: 1 , Pacific Ocean: 1 , Tyrrhenian Sea: 17 ;
total: 53 .

Record numbers (FAO classification): FAO 21 : 1 , FAO 27 : 1 , FAO 31 : 1 , FAO 37 : 49 , FAO 77 : 1 ;
total: 53 .

Remarks: Although the type locality of this taxon is on the Atlantic coast of the USA , most reports for this species are from the Mediterranean basin. There has also been some confusion in the records indicating that other
Batillipes
taxa may belong to
B. dicrocercus
(see e.g.
Maucci & Durante ( 1984 )
,
Hummon ( 1994 )
and Rodriguez-Roda (1947 , 1952 ) who recorded
B. mirus
in Spain ). Similarly, some
B. dicrocercus
records may belong to different taxa. For example,
Hummon ( 1994 )
reported
B. dicrocercus
from Poland , which has been questioned by
Zawierucha et al. ( 2015 )
, who suggested it belonged to
B. noerrevangi
.
Batillipes dicrocercus
has been reported from different types of sand and detritus in the intertidal zone, and has occasionally been collected in the subtidal down to ca. 80 m bsl.
